intro: Hieracium laevigatum subsp. tridentaticeps, commonly known as the three-toothed hawkweed, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It typically grows to a height of 20–60 cm and features basal leaves that are broadly ovate to elliptic in shape. The plant produces yellow composite flowers arranged in a flat-topped inflorescence, which bloom from late spring to early autumn. Its leaves are often hairy and have three distinct teeth along the margins, giving it its common name. This species is often found in meadows, grasslands, and disturbed soils, and it is characterized by its robust growth and adaptability to various environmental conditions.
